questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
A ExamTopics company has a Microsoft 365 subscription.
A user reports that they cannot add a guest user to a team.
You need to resolve this issue.
Which action you should perform? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
Is "add the guest to the team from the Teams admin center" really the right answer?
I would go for "add the guests domain to the allowed domains list"
Why?
Because if you can a domain there, then guest access must be enabled and when adding the domain to the list, it must work to add the guest user to the team.

comments.content: Solution got changed at this question. Now it's enable guest access.
There is no "guest domain", there is an external domain :)

discussion.content: Also, if "enable Allow third-party apps" switch is off, NO one would see the third party apps.

Selected Answer: B
user-specific, globally already allowed

Selected Answer: B
I agree that key words here are "New employees", so the answer is B

Selected Answer: B
Key here is "New employees are not able to find and install third-party apps." ie new employees are unable to access - so app permission policy which allows access needs to be applied.

Selected Answer: B
I think B is the correct answer
it is mentioned "An organization's users work with third-party apps in Microsoft Teams" So the org-wide app settings already allows third pary app.

comments.content: If that was the case then it would impact the existing employees as well. The question states it only impacts new employees.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
The Teams org-wide app settings should override any other app permission policy, so it should also be a correct answer. see docs: "Org-wide app settings override the global policy and any custom policies that you create and assign to users."

questions.question_text:
An organization's users work with third-party apps in Microsoft Teams.
New employees are not able to find and install third-party apps.
You need to resolve the issue.
What should you do?

choices.C: In the Org-wide app settings section of the Teams admin center, enable Allow interaction with custom apps.
choices.A: In the Org-wide app settings section of the Teams admin center, enable Allow third-party apps.
choices.B: Assign an app permission policy that allows third-party apps.

questions.question_text:
A company deploys Microsoft Teams by using Microsoft Endpoint Configuration Manager.
The Teams app that you installed is more than three months old. You plan to update all user devices to a newer version of the app.
You need to prepare the environment for the new deployment.
Which three actions should you perform? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

choices.C: Recursively delete all folders under the parent folder %localappdata\Microsoft\Teams\.
choices.D: Uninstall the Teams app for every user profile.

choices.C: On the Users page of the Azure Active Directory admin center, disable the app.
choices.D: On the Manage apps page of the Teams admin center, disable the app.
choices.E: On the Setup policies page of the Teams admin center, create a custom policy and assign the policy to users.
choices.A: On the Permission policies page of the Teams admin center, create a custom policy and assign the policy to users.
choices.B: On the Enterprise applications page in the Azure Active Directory admin center, disable the app.

questions.question_text:
A ExamTopics company uses Microsoft Teams.
You need to prevent users from using a specific app within Teams.
What are two possible ways to achieve this goal? Each correct answer presents a complete solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
MS 740 Training Material - https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/learn/modules/troubleshoot-apps-channels/2-troubleshoot-issues-apps?ns-enrollment-type=LearningPath&ns-enrollment-id=learn.wwl.troubleshoot-microsoft-365-teams

Apps in Azure AD - Tenant administrators and developers often have requirements where an application must be restricted to a certain set of users. There are two ways to restrict an application to a certain set of users or security groups:

Developers can use popular authorization patterns like Azure role-based access control (Azure RBAC).
Tenant administrators and developers can use built-in feature of Azure AD.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/develop/howto-restrict-your-app-to-a-set-of-users

Selected Answer: AD
I think this is the correct answer because the question mention app restrictions on Teams level only, so it's A and D.
Why not B when you can disable an app from Enterprise Applications via Azure AD? Is it because it does not specify that it is an Enterprise App?

comments.content: It cannot be B. If it is disabled at AAD level, then it affects other products as well and not just Teams.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
Seems correct as the app can be blocked in both these settings.

questions.question_text:
A company plans to grant a team named Human Resources access to a custom app called App1. The company plans to block users from adding any other third- party apps to the team.
Users report that they are unable to add App1 to the team.
You need to make sure that users can access App1.
Which three actions should you perform? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

choices.B: Run the following PowerShell command: Grant-CsTeamsAppSetupPolicy -Identity "HR Team" -PolicyNameHRAppSetupPolicy
choices.A: Run the following PowerShell command: Grant-CsTeamsAppPermissionPolicy -Identity "HR Team" -PolicyNameHRAppPermissionPolicy
choices.D: Create a custom app permission policy.
choices.E: Create a custom app setup policy.
choices.C: On the Manage apps page, ensure that App1 is allowed at the org level.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ACD
The answer is correct, see the docs
